elements.content: Two new heterometallic coordination polymers, [Na4Ln12(stp)8(OH)16(H2O)12]·10H2O [Ln = Dy (1) and Ho (2)], have been prepared from monosodium 2-sulfoterephthalate (NaH2stp), dysprosium acetate, or holmium acetate. They are isostructural, possessing a [Ln12(μ3-OH)16]20+ wheel-cluster core based on four vertex-sharing cubane-like [Ln4(μ3-OH)4]8+ units. The Ln12 cores are linked by stp ligands into a three-dimensional (3D) architecture. Magnetic studies indicate that complex 1 exhibits slow relaxation of magnetization, and it can be regarded as the first 3D coordination assembly of a Dy12 cluster single-molecule magnet.
elements.clean_text: Two new heterometallic coordination polymers, [Na4Ln12(stp)8(OH)16(H2O)12]⋅10H2O [Ln = Dy (1) and Ho (2)], have been prepared from monosodium 2-sulfoterephthalate (NaH2stp), dysprosium acetate, or holmium acetate. They are isostructural, possessing a [Ln12(μ3-OH)16]20+ wheel-cluster core based on four vertex-sharing cubane-like [Ln4(μ3-OH)4]8+ units. The Ln12 cores are linked by stp ligands into a three-dimensional (3D) architecture. Magnetic studies indicate that complex 1 exhibits slow relaxation of magnetization, and it can be regarded as the first 3D coordination assembly of a Dy12 cluster single-molecule magnet.

elements.content: Two new coordination polymers possessing a wheel-cluster core based on four vertex-sharing cubane-like [Ln4(μ3-OH)4]8+ units were prepared. The Dy12 cores are linked by 2-sulfoterephthalate ligands into a three-dimensional (3D) architecture with slow relaxation of magnetization, and it can be regarded as the first 3D coordination assembly of Dy12 cluster single-molecule magnet.
elements.clean_text: Two new coordination polymers possessing a wheel-cluster core based on four vertex-sharing cubane-like [Ln4(μ3-OH)4]8+ units were prepared. The Dy12 cores are linked by 2-sulfoterephthalate ligands into a three-dimensional (3D) architecture with slow relaxation of magnetization, and it can be regarded as the first 3D coordination assembly of Dy12 cluster single-molecule magnet.

elements.content: As a type of new species, polynuclear lanthanide complexes have been attractive for their charming structural features and peculiar potential applications in the fields of catalysis, magnetism, photoluminescence, and absorption of gas. High coordination numbers and large ionic radii of lanthanide ions result in the structural complication and varieties of polynuclear lanthanide complexes. The hydroxyl group plays a crucial role in the formation of the species because it may be the shortest linker for lanthanide ions with μ2-, μ3-, and μ4-bridging fashion. Many such lanthanide hydroxyl complexes featuring different polynuclear lanthanide geometries have been reported, for instance, a Ln4 square-shaped cyclic core or cubane-like unit, a Ln6 octahedral structure, Ln7 and Ln8 bis-cubane units, a Ln12 four vertex-sharing cubane-like unit, a Ln15 five vertex-sharing cubane-like unit, and even Ln26 cage-shaped clusters. For the Ln12 cluster based on a vertex-sharing cubane-like unit, only discrete structures were reported.
elements.clean_text: As a type of new species, polynuclear lanthanide complexes have been attractive for their charming structural features and peculiar potential applications in the fields of catalysis, magnetism, photoluminescence, and absorption of gas. High coordination numbers and large ionic radii of lanthanide ions result in the structural complication and varieties of polynuclear lanthanide complexes. The hydroxyl group plays a crucial role in the formation of the species because it may be the shortest linker for lanthanide ions with μ2-, μ3-, and μ4-bridging fashion. Many such lanthanide hydroxyl complexes featuring different polynuclear lanthanide geometries have been reported, for instance, a Ln4 square-shaped cyclic core or cubane-like unit, a Ln6 octahedral structure, Ln7 and Ln8 bis-cubane units, a Ln12 four vertex-sharing cubane-like unit, a Ln15 five vertex-sharing cubane-like unit, and even Ln26 cage-shaped clusters. For the Ln12 cluster based on a vertex-sharing cubane-like unit, only discrete structures were reported.

elements.content: Recently, slow relaxation and quantum tunneling of magnetization of single-molecule magnets (SMMs) have inspired exploration of the magnetic properties of polynuclear lanthanide complexes, especially Dy3+ complexes because of the strong magnetic anisotropy of lanthanides. The slow magnetic relaxations were observed not only in mononuclear lanthanide complexes but also in polynuclear 4f or 3d–4f discrete complexes. The three-dimensional (3D) lanthanide coordination polymers or lanthanide–organic frameworks have been reported widely; however, 3D structures possessing SMM behavior are scarce. To the best of our knowledge, the reported SMMs based on Dy12 clusters are discrete. To explore the 3D SMMs, there must be more significant research for their complicated structures, magnetic properties, and potential applications.
elements.clean_text: Recently, slow relaxation and quantum tunneling of magnetization of single-molecule magnets (SMMs) have inspired exploration of the magnetic properties of polynuclear lanthanide complexes, especially Dy3+ complexes because of the strong magnetic anisotropy of lanthanides. The slow magnetic relaxations were observed not only in mononuclear lanthanide complexes but also in polynuclear 4f or 3d-4f discrete complexes. The three-dimensional (3D) lanthanide coordination polymers or lanthanide-organic frameworks have been reported widely; however, 3D structures possessing SMM behavior are scarce. To the best of our knowledge, the reported SMMs based on Dy12 clusters are discrete. To explore the 3D SMMs, there must be more significant research for their complicated structures, magnetic properties, and potential applications.

elements.content: We prepared two 3D lanthanide hydroxo frameworks based on dodecanuclear dysprosium/holmium(III) hydroxo cluster cores, [Ln12(μ3-OH)16]20+, which were assembled into 3D frameworks via μ5-2-sulfoterephthalate (stp) ligands and Na+ template ions. Notably, the dysprosium complex exhibits slow relaxation of magnetization, which can be regarded as the first 3D coordination assembly of Dy12 cluster SMMs.
elements.clean_text: We prepared two 3D lanthanide hydroxo frameworks based on dodecanuclear dysprosium/holmium(III) hydroxo cluster cores, [Ln12(μ3-OH)16]20+, which were assembled into 3D frameworks via μ5-2-sulfoterephthalate (stp) ligands and Na+ template ions. Notably, the dysprosium complex exhibits slow relaxation of magnetization, which can be regarded as the first 3D coordination assembly of Dy12 cluster SMMs.

elements.content: Hexagonal crystals of [Na4Ln12(stp)8(OH)16(H2O)12]·10H2O [Ln = Dy (1) and Ho (2)] were obtained by the hydrothermal reaction of Ln(OAc)3, NaOAc, and 2-NaH2stp in water at 180 °C for 3 days. Single-crystal X-ray diffraction analyses indicated that compounds 1 and 2 are isomorphous. They possess porous frameworks based on Ln12 cores, with the Na+ ions and the water molecules occupying the channels. Herein, only the structure of 1 will be described in detail. In the asymmetrical unit, there are three Dy3+ ions, one Na+ ion, two stp3– anions, four OH– anions, three coordination water molecules, and two and a half lattice water molecules. All four crystallographically independent Dy3+ ions (Dy1, Dy2, Dy3, and Dy4 in Figure a) of 1 are in the distorted eight-coordinated anti-square-prism geometry, as shown in Figure S1 in the (SI). They are coordinated by oxygen atoms from stp3– anions, OH– anions, and water molecules. Two Na+ ions (Na1 and Na2) lie in different environments: Na1 is in a five-coordinated trigonal-bipyramidal configuration with two sulfonate oxygen atoms of two stp3– anions and three oxygen atoms from water molecules, while Na2 exists in a square-shaped geometry constructed by two carboxyl oxygen atoms and two hydroxyl atoms with weak coordination interaction (the bond lengths of Na2–O11 and Na2–O15 are 2.626 and 2.874 Å, respectively; Figure S2 in the ). The stp3– ligand adopts two different kinds of μ5-coordinated fashions connecting four Dy3+ ions and one Na+ ion, as shown in Scheme S1 in the .
elements.clean_text: Hexagonal crystals of [Na4Ln12(stp)8(OH)16(H2O)12]⋅10H2O [Ln = Dy (1) and Ho (2)] were obtained by the hydrothermal reaction of Ln(OAc)3, NaOAc, and 2-NaH2stp in water at 180 °C for 3 days. Single-crystal X-ray diffraction analyses indicated that compounds 1 and 2 are isomorphous. They possess porous frameworks based on Ln12 cores, with the Na+ ions and the water molecules occupying the channels. Herein, only the structure of 1 will be described in detail. In the asymmetrical unit, there are three Dy3+ ions, one Na+ ion, two stp3- anions, four OH- anions, three coordination water molecules, and two and a half lattice water molecules. All four crystallographically independent Dy3+ ions (Dy1, Dy2, Dy3, and Dy4 in Figure a) of 1 are in the distorted eight-coordinated anti-square-prism geometry, as shown in Figure S1 in the  (SI). They are coordinated by oxygen atoms from stp3- anions, OH- anions, and water molecules. Two Na+ ions (Na1 and Na2) lie in different environments: Na1 is in a five-coordinated trigonal-bipyramidal configuration with two sulfonate oxygen atoms of two stp3- anions and three oxygen atoms from water molecules, while Na2 exists in a square-shaped geometry constructed by two carboxyl oxygen atoms and two hydroxyl atoms with weak coordination interaction (the bond lengths of Na2-O11 and Na2-O15 are 2.626 and 2.874 Å, respectively; Figure S2 in the ). The stp3- ligand adopts two different kinds of μ5-coordinated fashions connecting four Dy3+ ions and one Na+ ion, as shown in Scheme S1 in the .

elements.content: (a) Coordination environment of four Dy3+ ions in 1. (b) [Dy12(μ3-OH)16]20+ cluster core showing the lantern-like cage formed by two Na ions and the central Dy4O8 atoms. Symmetry operation: (A) 1 – x, y, −z; (B) 1 – x, 2 – y, −z; (C) x, 2 – y, z; (D) 1.5 – x, 0.5 + y, −z; (E) −0.5 + x, 0.5 + y, z.

Symmetry operation: (A) 1 - x, y, -z; (B) 1 - x, 2 - y, -z; (C) x, 2 - y, z; (D) 1.5 - x, 0.5 + y, -z; (E) -0.5 + x, 0.5 + y, z.

elements.content: As shown in Figure b, the Dy1, Dy2, and two Dy3 ions are bridged by four μ3-OH groups (O17, O18, O19, and O18C) into a cubane-like unit, similar to the cubic unit based on two Dy4 and two Dy3 ions. Such four cubane-like [Dy4(μ3-OH)4]8+ units are linked by Dy3 knots end to end into a vertex-sharing dodecanuclear core. Two Na+ ions (Na2D and Na2E) together with the central Dy3, O15, O17, and O19 form a Dy4O8Na2 lantern-like cage with a cavity of 3.75 × 3.96 × 2.54 Å. The adjacent dodecanuclear cores are linked along the c axis by two μ2-oxygen atoms (O21) from water molecules coordinating with the Dy1 ions (the bond length of Dy1–O21 is 2.455 Å) into a one-dimensional (1D) chain (Figure ).
elements.clean_text: As shown in Figure b, the Dy1, Dy2, and two Dy3 ions are bridged by four μ3-OH groups (O17, O18, O19, and O18C) into a cubane-like unit, similar to the cubic unit based on two Dy4 and two Dy3 ions. Such four cubane-like [Dy4(μ3-OH)4]8+ units are linked by Dy3 knots end to end into a vertex-sharing dodecanuclear core. Two Na+ ions (Na2D and Na2E) together with the central Dy3, O15, O17, and O19 form a Dy4O8Na2 lantern-like cage with a cavity of 3.75 × 3.96 × 2.54 Å. The adjacent dodecanuclear cores are linked along the c axis by two μ2-oxygen atoms (O21) from water molecules coordinating with the Dy1 ions (the bond length of Dy1-O21 is 2.455 Å) into a one-dimensional (1D) chain (Figure ).

elements.content: 3D metal–organic framework of 1, showing a 1D chain formed by Dy12 units along the c axis.
elements.clean_text: 2  3D metal-organic framework of 1, showing a 1D chain formed by Dy12 units along the c axis.

elements.content: For the hydroxyl group in complex 1, there are two coordination modes: μ3- and μ4 bridges. Only one hydroxyl (O15) acts as μ4 bridge, linking Dy3, Dy4, Dy3A, and Na2D. The other hydroxyl (O16, O17, O18, and O19) acts as μ3 bridge, linking three Dy3+ ions. For coordination water molecules, only O21 acts as a μ2 bridge, and the other water molecules (O20, O22, O23, O24, and O25) are terminally coordinated. The stp3– ligand serves as a multidentate ligand in a μ5-coordinated fashion and bridges these 1D dodecanuclear chains into a 3D framework in four directions through the oxygen atoms of the carboxyl and sulfonate groups of the stp3– ligands (Figure ). From the c axis, there are 1D channels based on these 1D dodecanuclear chains and stp3– ligands, in which Na+ ions (Na1) and coordination and lattice water molecules are filled in. The Na+ ions (Na1) as a template in the channels are coordinated by extending the oxygen atoms (O7) from the sulfonate groups of the stp3– ligands. The total void volume, V void, within complex 1 without the fillings is 25% per unit volume, as determined by PLATON.
elements.clean_text: For the hydroxyl group in complex 1, there are two coordination modes: μ3- and μ4 bridges. Only one hydroxyl (O15) acts as μ4 bridge, linking Dy3, Dy4, Dy3A, and Na2D. The other hydroxyl (O16, O17, O18, and O19) acts as μ3 bridge, linking three Dy3+ ions. For coordination water molecules, only O21 acts as a μ2 bridge, and the other water molecules (O20, O22, O23, O24, and O25) are terminally coordinated. The stp3- ligand serves as a multidentate ligand in a μ5-coordinated fashion and bridges these 1D dodecanuclear chains into a 3D framework in four directions through the oxygen atoms of the carboxyl and sulfonate groups of the stp3- ligands (Figure ). From the c axis, there are 1D channels based on these 1D dodecanuclear chains and stp3- ligands, in which Na+ ions (Na1) and coordination and lattice water molecules are filled in. The Na+ ions (Na1) as a template in the channels are coordinated by extending the oxygen atoms (O7) from the sulfonate groups of the stp3- ligands. The total void volume, V void, within complex 1 without the fillings is 25% per unit volume, as determined by PLATON.

elements.content: In order to classify the topology of the network, suitable nodes should be defined. The dodecanuclear Dy12 cluster is considered to be a 20-connected node surrounded by 16 stp ligands and four μ2-H2O molecules. The stp ligand connected to two Dy12 clusters can be considered a 2-connected node. The ligand μ2-H2O linking two Dy12 clusters is considered to be a 2-connected node. Figure S3 in the shows the topological diagram.
elements.clean_text: In order to classify the topology of the network, suitable nodes should be defined. The dodecanuclear Dy12 cluster is considered to be a 20-connected node surrounded by 16 stp ligands and four μ2-H2O molecules. The stp ligand connected to two Dy12 clusters can be considered a 2-connected node. The ligand μ2-H2O linking two Dy12 clusters is considered to be a 2-connected node. Figure S3 in the  shows the topological diagram.

elements.content: The phase purity of 1 was confirmed by powder X-ray diffraction, as shown in Figure S4 in the . Considering the longer lifetime luminescence of the Dy3+ ion, the luminescent property of 1 was investigated in the solid state at room temperature. As shown in Figure S5 in the , its emission spectrum exhibited the characteristic narrow bands (481, 543, 589, 633, and 697 nm) arising from the 4F9/2 → 6H15/2, 4F9/2 → 6H13/2, 4I15/2 → 6H11/2, 4F9/2 → 6H11/2, and 4I15/2 → 6H9/2 transitions of the Dy3+ ion when excited at 392 nm.
elements.clean_text: The phase purity of 1 was confirmed by powder X-ray diffraction, as shown in Figure S4 in the . Considering the longer lifetime luminescence of the Dy3+ ion, the luminescent property of 1 was investigated in the solid state at room temperature. As shown in Figure S5 in the , its emission spectrum exhibited the characteristic narrow bands (481, 543, 589, 633, and 697 nm) arising from the 4F9/2 → 6H15/2, 4F9/2 → 6H13/2, 4I15/2 → 6H11/2, 4F9/2 → 6H11/2, and 4I15/2 → 6H9/2 transitions of the Dy3+ ion when excited at 392 nm.

elements.content: The temperature dependence of the magnetic susceptibility of complex 1 has been carried out in the range 2–300 K under an external magnetic field of 1 kOe. The plot of χM T (with χM being the magnetic susceptibility per lanthanide ion) versus T is shown in Figure . The χM T value at 300 K is 166.52 cm3 K mol–1, which is slightly lower than the expected value of 170.04 cm3 K mol–1 for noncoupling spins of 12 Dy3+ (S = 5/2, L = 5, g = 4/3, 6H15/2, and C = 14.17 cm3Kmol–1) but consistent with the data reported in the literature. With decreasing temperature, the χM T value continuously decreases to reach a value of 114.24 cm3 K mol–1 at 2.0 K. The overall behavior can be ascribed to depopulation of the Dy3+ Stark sublevels as well as the exchange interactions between the Dy3+ ions. The field-dependent magnetization at 2.0 K is shown in Figure S6 in the . The magnetization reveals a rapid increase at low field and reaches 63.44 Nβ at 7 T, in good agreement with the expected value of 62.76 Nβ (12 × 5.23 Nβ) for 12 noninteracting Dy3+ ions, assuming the presence of considerable ligand-field effects. However, no saturation is achieved, which indicates the presence of magnetic anisotropy and/or low-lying excited states in the system.
elements.clean_text: The temperature dependence of the magnetic susceptibility of complex 1 has been carried out in the range 2-300 K under an external magnetic field of 1 kOe. The plot of χM T (with χM being the magnetic susceptibility per lanthanide ion) versus T is shown in Figure . The χM T value at 300 K is 166.52 cm3 K mol-1, which is slightly lower than the expected value of 170.04 cm3 K mol-1 for noncoupling spins of 12 Dy3+ (S = 5/2, L = 5, g = 4/3, 6H15/2, and C = 14.17 cm3Kmol-1) but consistent with the data reported in the literature. With decreasing temperature, the χM T value continuously decreases to reach a value of 114.24 cm3 K mol-1 at 2.0 K. The overall behavior can be ascribed to depopulation of the Dy3+ Stark sublevels as well as the exchange interactions between the Dy3+ ions. The field-dependent magnetization at 2.0 K is shown in Figure S6 in the . The magnetization reveals a rapid increase at low field and reaches 63.44 Nβ at 7 T, in good agreement with the expected value of 62.76 Nβ (12 × 5.23 Nβ) for 12 noninteracting Dy3+ ions, assuming the presence of considerable ligand-field effects. However, no saturation is achieved, which indicates the presence of magnetic anisotropy and/or low-lying excited states in the system.

elements.content: χM T versus T plot for the dysprosium complex.
elements.clean_text: 3  χM T versus T plot for the dysprosium complex.

elements.content: To study the spin dynamics, alternating-current (ac) magnetic susceptibilities were measured under a zero direct-current (dc) field with an ac field of 2.5 Oe with oscillating frequencies. As shown in Figure , both in-phase (χ′) and out-of-phase (χ″) signals show frequency-dependent peak maxima, typical of slow magnetic relaxation. The magnetization relaxation time (τ) is plotted as a function of 1/T in Figure S7 in the . Fitting to the Arrhenius law, τ = τ0 exp(Δτ/kT), afforded an energy gap (Δτ) of 13.66 K and a preexponential factor (τ0) of 8.82 × 10–7 s (R = 0.999), which is in agreement with the expected characteristic relaxation time of 10–6–10–11 s for SMMs. The obtained anisotropic energy barrier is comparable to those previously reported for dysprosium-based metal–organic frameworks. The frequency dependencies of the ac susceptibilities were measured at 2.0 and 2.5 K, respectively. The data plotted as Cole–Cole plots show a quasi-semicircular shape (Figure S8 in the ), and these can be fitted to the generalized Debye model with α = 0.29 and 0.27, indicating the presence of a wide distribution of relaxation time in the dysprosium complex.
elements.clean_text: To study the spin dynamics, alternating-current (ac) magnetic susceptibilities were measured under a zero direct-current (dc) field with an ac field of 2.5 Oe with oscillating frequencies. As shown in Figure , both in-phase (χ') and out-of-phase (χ") signals show frequency-dependent peak maxima, typical of slow magnetic relaxation. The magnetization relaxation time (τ) is plotted as a function of 1/T in Figure S7 in the . Fitting to the Arrhenius law, τ = τ0 exp(Δτ/kT), afforded an energy gap (Δτ) of 13.66 K and a preexponential factor (τ0) of 8.82 × 10-7 s (R = 0.999), which is in agreement with the expected characteristic relaxation time of 10-6-10-11 s for SMMs. The obtained anisotropic energy barrier is comparable to those previously reported for dysprosium-based metal-organic frameworks. The frequency dependencies of the ac susceptibilities were measured at 2.0 and 2.5 K, respectively. The data plotted as Cole-Cole plots show a quasi-semicircular shape (Figure S8 in the ), and these can be fitted to the generalized Debye model with α = 0.29 and 0.27, indicating the presence of a wide distribution of relaxation time in the dysprosium complex.

elements.content: Temperature dependence of the in-phase (a) and out-of phase (b) ac susceptibility of the dysprosium complex in a zero dc magnetic field.
elements.clean_text: 4  Temperature dependence of the in-phase (a) and out-of phase (b) ac susceptibility of the dysprosium complex in a zero dc magnetic field.

elements.content: For lanthanide-based compounds, slow magnetic relaxation is often attributed to single-ion behavior due to weak exchange interactions between the lanthanide ions, in which the symmetry of the local crystal field around the lanthanide ions plays a critical role. Regarding this, all dysprosium ions are in an approximately square-antiprismatic environment in complex 1, as in other well-known dysprosium complexes with SMM behavior; thus, magnetic relaxation of 1 is mainly ascribed to the dysprosium ion behavior. Noticeably, the weak Dy–Dy exchange coupling transmitted by the OH group may play an important role in magnetic relaxation because it can suppress the quantum tunneling of magnetization. As shown in the structure, the complex is composed of large Dy12 cluster units, which can be regarded as the fusion of four vertex-sharing cubane-like Dy4 units. Thus, this dysprosium derivative can be regarded as the first 3D coordination assembly of Dy12 cluster SMMs.
elements.clean_text: For lanthanide-based compounds, slow magnetic relaxation is often attributed to single-ion behavior due to weak exchange interactions between the lanthanide ions, in which the symmetry of the local crystal field around the lanthanide ions plays a critical role. Regarding this, all dysprosium ions are in an approximately square-antiprismatic environment in complex 1, as in other well-known dysprosium complexes with SMM behavior; thus, magnetic relaxation of 1 is mainly ascribed to the dysprosium ion behavior. Noticeably, the weak Dy-Dy exchange coupling transmitted by the OH group may play an important role in magnetic relaxation because it can suppress the quantum tunneling of magnetization. As shown in the structure, the complex is composed of large Dy12 cluster units, which can be regarded as the fusion of four vertex-sharing cubane-like Dy4 units. Thus, this dysprosium derivative can be regarded as the first 3D coordination assembly of Dy12 cluster SMMs.

elements.content: In summary, two novel isomorphous lanthanide complexes based on the cluster [Ln12(μ3-OH)16]20+ have been obtained. The dodecanuclear cluster consists of four vertex-sharing cubane-like clusters. The Ln12 clusters are linked by μ2-H2O and stp ligands to 3D metal–organic frameworks with 1D channels. In the channels, Na+ ions and lattice water molecules are located. The magnetic property of 1 exhibits slow relaxation of magnetization, and all Dy3+ ions are in an approximately square-antiprismatic environment, as in other well-known dysprosium complexes with SMM behavior, so the title dysprosium complex can be regarded as the first 3D coordination assembly of Dy12 cluster SMMs.
elements.clean_text: In summary, two novel isomorphous lanthanide complexes based on the cluster [Ln12(μ3-OH)16]20+ have been obtained. The dodecanuclear cluster consists of four vertex-sharing cubane-like clusters. The Ln12 clusters are linked by μ2-H2O and stp ligands to 3D metal-organic frameworks with 1D channels. In the channels, Na+ ions and lattice water molecules are located. The magnetic property of 1 exhibits slow relaxation of magnetization, and all Dy3+ ions are in an approximately square-antiprismatic environment, as in other well-known dysprosium complexes with SMM behavior, so the title dysprosium complex can be regarded as the first 3D coordination assembly of Dy12 cluster SMMs.

elements.content: X-ray crystallographic data in CIF format, detailed experimental procedures, powder X-ray diffraction pattern, emission spectrum, and additional structural and magnetic data for complex 1. This material is available free of charge via the Internet at http://pubs.acs.org.

metadata.title:
Three-Dimensional
Frameworks Based on Dodecanuclear
Dy–hydroxo Wheel Cluster with Slow Relaxation of Magnetization
